<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">SWK2110</span> - Social welfare and the law<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-SWK2110">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-social-work.html">Department of Social Work</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Margaret Alston">Professor Margaret Alston</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Kerry Brydon">Dr Kerry Brydon</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-SWK2110">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will broadly explore the legal mandate and legal processes through which policies in social welfare are implemented. It will also consider key legal dilemmas that impact on social welfare service delivery.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Outline the origins and purpose of the law, including human rights considerations, particularly as applicable to children and older people.</li>
<li>Identify the values and principles that underpin the law including the nature of ethics and ethical practice, how these apply in practice and tensions that may arise.</li>
<li>Identify the legal systems and terminology that may affect individuals and families with particular reference to the child welfare and aged care groups.</li>
<li>Discuss how legal frameworks and welfare service delivery systems interact.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Report of student attendance at a Court or Tribunal hearing (2,000 words) (45%)</li>
<li>Assignment (2,500 words) (55%)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Students will attend up to three hours of direct teaching classes per week and are expected to complete nine hours of independent study each week.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/health-science">Health science</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">BIO1022</span> - Life on Earth<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BIO1022">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-biological-sciences.html">School of Biological Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Richard Burke">Dr Richard Burke</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Richard Burke">Dr Richard Burke</a>
        
        (Clayton)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Lee Wai Leng">Dr Lee Wai Leng</a>
        
        (Malaysia, S2)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Patrick Tan Hock Siew">Dr Patrick Tan Hock Siew</a>
        
        (Malaysia, OCT-MY-01)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BIO1022&amp;tpCode=OCT-MY-01&amp;tpYear=2019">October intake</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BIO1022&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BIO1022">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>October intake 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>BIO1711, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BMS1021.html">BMS1021</a></span></p>
<p>Students in S2007 Bachelor of Science and Bachelor of Biomedical Science are prohibited from enrolling in this unit.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit views the extraordinary diversity of life on Earth through the prism of evolutionary theory and in the context of human and environmental health. Students will examine how animals and plants, through the agents of gene mutation and natural selection, are able to adapt to new and changing environments. Diverse physiological, reproductive and behavioural solutions to life's challenges will be used to illustrate how evolutionary forces and constraints shape us and the world around us. We will then examine how interactions within and between species and with the non-living environment generate the immense ecological variety seen on Earth. Contemporary issues and the societal impact of biology will be explored by learning from world-class researchers and industry experts.</p>
<p>Students will undertake self-directed learning through the online environment. These online activities, readings and instructional videos will be complemented by face-to-face workshops where they will collaborate with peers and teaching staff to deepen their understanding of the biological concepts introduced each week. Students will gain hands-on experience and develop experimental and analytical skills in the laboratory environment. Optional drop-in tutorials are available for additional learning support. This unit is ideally paired with <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BIO1011.html">BIO1011</a></span> and/or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BIO1042.html">BIO1042</a></span>.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Identify and describe the role of biological concepts and processes of evolution, plant and animal physiology, reproduction and life history strategies and core ecological concepts in society and everyday human life;</li>
<li>Demonstrate proficiency in communicating scientific results through a range of formats (written and oral);</li>
<li>Formulate hypotheses, collect experimental data and demonstrate proficiency in interpreting their results;</li>
<li>Demonstrate competence and precision in the use of common life sciences equipment and techniques;</li>
<li>Utilise research skills including database searches to synthesise and interpret information related to scientific research, using appropriate conventions for scientific attribution;</li>
<li>Work effectively, responsibly, safely and ethically, both individually and in peer or team contexts.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 50%</p>
<p>Continuous assessment through laboratory classes and online activities: 50% (Hurdle)</p>
<p>Hurdle requirement: Students must attend at least 80% of workshops and laboratory classes to be eligible to pass this unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>One 1-hour workshop and</li>
<li>1.5-2 hours online activities per week</li>
<li>Six 3-hour practicals per semester</li>
</ul><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/applied-microbiology">Applied microbiology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/biochemistry">Biochemistry</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/biotechnology">Biotechnology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/developmental-biology">Developmental biology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/ecology-and-conservation-biology">Ecology and conservation biology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/genetics">Genetics</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/human-pathology">Human pathology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/immunology">Immunology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/microbiology">Microbiology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/molecular-biology">Molecular biology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/pharmacology">Pharmacology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/physiology">Physiology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/plant-sciences">Plant sciences</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/tropical-environmental-biology">Tropical environmental biology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/zoology">Zoology</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">PAR2022</span> - Paramedic management of trauma conditions<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-PAR2022">

         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>

<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-PAR2022">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-peninsula.html">Peninsula</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/PAR2011.html">PAR2011</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/PAR2021.html">PAR2021</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/PAR2031.html">PAR2031</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Course code M2011</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>EPP2042, BEH2022</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit continues to develop the role of the paramedic as a clinician by extending clinical examination and decision making skills that were introduced in previous clinical units.</p>
<p>The unit addresses injury and injury prevention across the lifespan, with specific reference to commonly encountered acute and chronic musculoskeletal conditions, injury.</p>
<p>The unit will be case based, and will include clinical skills laboratories and simulation to develop essential clinical skills, clinical problem solving and decision making competencies. The scope of the unit includes developing the skills needed to provide general health care as well as care at an advanced life support level.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Describe the epidemiology, population health and pathology related to injuries and commonly encountered in paramedic practice.</li>
<li>Describe criteria used to identify major trauma and demonstrate the application of pre-hospital trauma triage guidelines.</li>
<li>Identify and evaluate evidence that informs paramedic clinical practice guidelines used to care for patients with injury.</li>
<li>Relate the pharmacology of drugs and fluids used by paramedics for the management of injury to drug indications and actions.</li>
<li>Demonstrate the ability to integrate the theoretical knowledge and clinical skills to the assessment and management of patients with injury in real time simulation.</li>
<li>Demonstrate clinical reasoning skills related to the management of trauma patients.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Weekly short MCQ tests (10 minutes) (10%)</li>
<li>Mid-semester examination (25%)</li>
<li>Clinical portfolio (25%)</li>
<li>End of semester examination (2 hours) (40%) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>End of semester practical scenario (Pass / Fail) (Hurdle)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>A combination of lectures, tutorials and online activities (6 hours per week), and self-directed study (6 hours per week).</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/paramedicine">Paramedicine</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">BEX5707</span> - Business insights from data analysis<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BEX5707">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Robert Brooks">Professor Robert Brooks</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Robert Brooks">Professor Robert Brooks</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BEX5707&amp;tpCode=WS-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Winter semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BEX5707">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Winter semester 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The first objective of this unit is for students to understand how data analysis techniques can produce insights to address a business problem. The second objective is for students to explore the journal and case literature on this topic in the setting of the sports industry. An applied approach will be taken involving some field visits. The unit will be delivered at a time to enable Monash Business School students drawn from multiple programs to interact with exchange and study abroad students from partner universities.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>develop an understanding of how to interpret data analysis and draw relevant insights in a business context</li>
<li>enhance report writing skills by developing an understanding of the process of preparing a business report based on insight gained from data analysis</li>
<li>enhance communication, interpersonal, problem solving and critical thinking capabilities</li>
<li>develop capabilities to be future generators of sustainable economic, social and environmental value for business.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">IMM3990</span> - Immunology in action research project<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-IMM3990">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Frank Alderuccio">Associate Professor Frank Alderuccio</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Mark Wright">Associate Professor Mark Wright</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=IMM3990&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=IMM3990&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=IMM3990&amp;tpCode=SSA-02&amp;tpYear=2019">Summer semester A</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-IMM3990">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Summer semester A 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Permission from the unit coordinator or head of department.</p>
<p>Students must have completed all 1st and 2nd level  units in their approved major and be able to demonstrate that they have an appropriate project and supervisor/s. 12 points of study in the discipline area at 2nd year level and a grade point average of at least 70 over 24 points in relevant units at 2nd year level.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>Additional information including application process is available from:</p>
<p><a href="https://sites.google.com/monash.edu/researchinactionunits/start-here">https://sites.google.com/monash.edu/researchinactionunits/start-here</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will provide high achieving students a structured research experience by participating in a research project supervised by research academics within, or associated with, the Department of Immunology. Research projects can be selected from a list of projects available from the Department of Immunology and Pathology. Students will learn skills in research design, implementation, data analysis and interpretation.  In addition, students will develop skills in scientific communication through written assignments and reports and oral presentations based on their project.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Undertake a research project with regard to ethical and safety regulations;</li>
<li>Demonstrate technical skills in experimental methods and the ability to collect, analyse and interpret data using methods relevant to the discipline of Immunology;</li>
<li>Communicate appropriately and effectively with supervisors, laboratory staff and students;</li>
<li>Maintain accurate and up-to-date records of experimental procedures, results and outcomes;</li>
<li>Identify relevant published scientific literature and critically analyse and evaluate the content in the context of the discipline of Immunology;</li>
<li>Construct written reports.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Oral reports : 20%</p>
<p>Written report (preliminary 1000 words): 10%</p>
<p>Written report (final 5000 words): 50% (Hurdle)</p>
<p>Assessment of laboratory work: 20%</p>
<p>This unit is subject to the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.med.monash.edu.au/policies/assessment-policy-2017.html">Hurdle and Threshold Standards policies</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Hurdle and Threshold Standards policies (<a href="http://www.med.monash.edu.au/policies/assessment-policy-2017.html">http://www.med.monash.edu.au/policies/assessment-policy-2017.html</a>)</span> of the Faculty of Medicine, Nursing &amp; Health Sciences.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 contact hours per week</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/immunology">Immunology</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MGX3441</span> - Human resource strategy<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MGX3441">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-management.html">Department of Management</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Cathy Sheehan">Associate Professor Cathy Sheehan</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Cathy Sheehan">Associate Professor Cathy Sheehan</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MGX3441&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MGX3441">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MGB2430.html">MGB2430</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MGC2430.html">MGC2430</a></span>, MGG2430, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MGF2661.html">MGF2661</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MGW2430.html">MGW2430</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit identifies and develops the thinking skills that enable the formulation of innovative HR strategies that advance organisational needs and objectives to achieve sustainable competitive advantage by critically examining the relationship between HRM and organisational strategies. Topics typically include: the external and global environment for HRM, the dynamics of industry-based competition, strategic flexibility, and characteristics of innovative and value-adding HR practices and systems.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>critically examine the theoretical links between strategy and HRM</li>
<li>critically analyse how HRM can be used as a strategic tool to gain competitive advantage with respect to the global context</li>
<li>formulate, evaluate and recommend solutions to strategic HRM problems</li>
<li>critically analyse strategic HRM theories and practices and their applications to organisational realities.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">MID2000</span> - Foundations for midwifery practice<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MID2000">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-nursing-and-midwifery.html">School of Nursing and Midwifery</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Anne Tremayne">Ms Anne Tremayne</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Anne Tremayne">Ms Anne Tremayne</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Quota applies</p>
<p>This unit is quota restricted. Selection is on a first-in, first enrolled basis.
      
      
      </p><p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MID2000&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MID2000">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-peninsula.html">Peninsula</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (Flexible)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MID1000.html">MID1000</a></span> and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR1114.html">NUR1114</a></span></p>
<p>OR</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BMA1901.html">BMA1901</a></span> and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR1010.html">NUR1010</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in course M3007 or 4514</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>MID1002, MID1003</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit introduces students to the foundational knowledge required by midwives to effectively care for women and their babies from preconception through to early parenting.</p>
<p>Students will explore the fundamental clinical skills required for contemporary midwifery practice in a variety of settings.</p>
<p>Learning will also focus on the physiological and psychosocial adaptation of the healthy woman and child, and the application of this understanding to the provision of woman centred midwifery care.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Explain in depth the normal maternal anatomical and physiological adaptations relevant to pregnancy, labour,
birth and the puerperium;</li>
<li>Apply the theoretical knowledge of the normal anatomical and physiological adaptations during pregnancy to
describe a woman-centred approach pivotal to midwifery practice for women of all cultural backgrounds;</li>
<li>Explain the role of the midwife in assessment of foetal and maternal well-being during pregnancy, labour, birth and
the puerperium;</li>
<li>Recognise the importance of using evidence to inform clinical practice and implement developing clinical
midwifery skills in the appraisal of mother and baby during pregnancy, labour, birth and postpartum;</li>
<li>Describe the midwifery skills required to provide comprehensive physical and psychosocial assessments
when providing maternity care for women and their babies across the childbearing continuum;</li>
<li>Differentiate the difference between screening and diagnostic tests and list the routine screening and basic
diagnostic tests in pregnancy, labour and birth assessment;</li>
<li>Explain the need for reflective practice in the implementation of evidence informed care;</li>
<li>Demonstrate developing midwifery competence based upon the Nursing and Midwifery (NMBA) 'Midwife standards for practice';</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Fieldwork</h2>
<div>
<p>80 hours clinical placement in a maternity unit.Students are required to participate in a two week clinical placement. In line with ANMAC requirements they are also required to undertake Continuity of Care relationships with women x 2.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Essay (3000 words) (30%)</li>
<li>Invigilated online test (1 hour) (15%)</li>
<li>Exam (2 hours) (40%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Clinical Placement Antenatal clinic including relevant learning tools (80 hours) (15%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Continuity of care clinical report x 2 or submission of reflective piece in Mid + Clinical Portfolio (500 words x 2) (Hurdle).</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Lectures (Teacher directed activity) 20 hours</li>
<li>Workshops/CLE: 20 hours (100% attendance required)</li>
<li>Weekly online guided activities: 60 hours</li>
<li>Self-directed learning: 60 hours</li>
<li>Clinical placement linked to skills assessment: 80 hours</li>
<li>Continuity of Care clinical hours: 20 hours</li>
</ul><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/nursing-and-midwifery">Nursing and midwifery</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_it"><span class="unitcode">FIT4441</span> - Honours thesis part 1<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-FIT4441">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_it">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-it.html">Information Technology</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Pari Delir Haghighi">Dr Pari Delir Haghighi</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT4441&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT4441&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-FIT4441">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-south-africa.html">South Africa</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Admission to an FIT Honours program.</p>
<p>Students in C3001 must have competed 144 credit points towards their degree including <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT2083.html">FIT2083</a></span>.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>For all students OTHER than C3001: <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT4005.html">FIT4005</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>CPE4000, CSE4000, IMS4000, FIT4126, FIT4186, FIT4246, FIT4606</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is a research unit and a core unit for all Faculty of Information Technology Honours degrees. Due to the nature of IT, a wide range of Honours project types can be offered to students. Some project components are of a practical nature and may involve some software development and/or experimentation, while other components are of a more theoretical nature.</p>
<p>This unit forms part of the sequence of units comprising the Honours thesis in the Faculty of Information Technology.</p>
<p>Two exit points exist for the Honours thesis, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT4444.html">FIT4444</a></span> (24 pts) and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT4448.html">FIT4448</a></span> (18 pts). The 24 credit point exit point is applicable to:</p>
<p>Bachelor of Business Information Systems (Honours), Bachelor of Computer Science (Honours), Honours degree of Bachelor of Computer and Information Sciences, Bachelor of Information Technology and Systems (Honours) and Bachelor of Informatics and Computation Advanced (Honours).</p>
<p>The 18 credit point exit point is applicable to:</p>
<p>Honours stream in the Bachelor of Software Engineering.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of the Honours thesis units, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>design a rigorous Bachelor Honours level research project and develop project proposal;</li>
<li>critically review research literature, research design and reported findings;</li>
<li>evaluate and select research methods and techniques of data collection and analysis appropriate to particular research designs, projects and disciplines;</li>
<li>conduct ethical research;</li>
<li>communicate research findings in written and oral form in research and industry settings.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>At the completion of the requirements for the thesis the following components of assessment will be completed:</p>
<p>Research Proposal: 5%; Literature Review: 10%; Interim Presentation: hurdle; Final Presentation: 5%; Thesis (normally 10,000 - 20,000 words): 80%</p>
<p>These assessment tasks will be completed over the course of several units in the Honours program but the overall grade for the thesis will only be finalised on completion of either <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT4444.html">FIT4444</a></span> (24 pts) or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT4448.html">FIT4448</a></span> (18 pts).</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload equals 12 hours per week. Students will be expected to hold regular meetings with supervisor(s) over the course of the semester.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MGX3441</span> - Human resource strategy<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MGX3441">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-management.html">Department of Management</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Cathy Sheehan">Associate Professor Cathy Sheehan</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Cathy Sheehan">Associate Professor Cathy Sheehan</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MGX3441&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MGX3441">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MGB2430.html">MGB2430</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MGC2430.html">MGC2430</a></span>, MGG2430, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MGF2661.html">MGF2661</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MGW2430.html">MGW2430</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit identifies and develops the thinking skills that enable the formulation of innovative HR strategies that advance organisational needs and objectives to achieve sustainable competitive advantage by critically examining the relationship between HRM and organisational strategies. Topics typically include: the external and global environment for HRM, the dynamics of industry-based competition, strategic flexibility, and characteristics of innovative and value-adding HR practices and systems.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>critically examine the theoretical links between strategy and HRM</li>
<li>critically analyse how HRM can be used as a strategic tool to gain competitive advantage with respect to the global context</li>
<li>formulate, evaluate and recommend solutions to strategic HRM problems</li>
<li>critically analyse strategic HRM theories and practices and their applications to organisational realities.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

</ul>
</nav>
<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_it"><span class="unitcode">FIT2101</span> - Software engineering process and management<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-FIT2101">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_it">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-it.html">Information Technology</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Robyn McNamara">Ms Robyn McNamara</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT2101&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-FIT2101">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>(<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ENG1003.html">ENG1003</a></span> and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ENG1060.html">ENG1060</a></span>) or one of <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT1045.html">FIT1045</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT1048.html">FIT1048</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT1051.html">FIT1051</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT1053.html">FIT1053</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>A disciplined process is vital to the success of any major software development project. In this unit, students learn essential skills for managing software development efforts and for working within coordinated teams. Students will learn how to decide upon and document their team's structure and their process model. They will be expected to follow the process model they have documented, and to evaluate its effectiveness.</p>
<p>There are many factors that can potentially cause a software project to fail. This unit will equip students with techniques to identify and manage these risks, and will take a risk-focused approach to project organisation.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>describe the nature and purpose of a software engineering process, including the historical evolution of the concept, and describe the major features of the most common process models;</li>
<li>document a software process in a project management plan, including process model, team organisation, risk management, and time management;</li>
<li>identify relevant risks for a small-to-medium size software project, analyse their impact and likelihood, identify appropriate mitigations, and document these in a risk matrix.;</li>
<li>elicit functional and non-functional requirements for a small-to-medium size software project from stakeholders through interview and/or document analysis techniques, capture these using appropriate methods for the given process model (including user stories and use cases), and analyse these requirements for completeness including test-ability;</li>
<li>apply a lightweight process to the development of a small software project in small groups, including the use of software engineering tools such as revision control and issue tracking systems, analyse their strengths and weaknesses and make recommendations for improving the process based on experience and observation.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 40%; In-semester assessment: 60%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload equals 12 hours per week comprising:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="a">
<li>Contact hours for on-campus students:

<ul>
<li>One hour lecture</li>
<li>Three hours laboratories</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Additional requirements (all students):

<ul>
<li>A minimum of 2-3 hours of personal study per one hour of lecture time in order to satisfy the reading, tute, prac and assignment expectations.</li>
</ul></li>
</ol><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/software-development">Software development</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/software-engineering">Software engineering</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS2295</span> - Screening contemporary Europe<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS2295">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-film-and-screen-studies.html">Film and Screen Studies</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Felicity Chaplin">Dr Felicity Chaplin</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Julia Vassilieva">Dr Julia Vassilieva</a>
<br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Felicity Chaplin">Dr Felicity Chaplin</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS2295&amp;tpCode=T3-58&amp;tpYear=2019">Trimester 3</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS2295">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-prato.html">Prato</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Trimester 3 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Two gateway units in either Film and screen studies, Communication and media studies, Journalism or approved equivalent.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS3295.html">ATS3295</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><ul>
<li>This unit is an <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://future.arts.monash.edu/learning-abroad">international study program</a><span class="hbk-print-url">international study program (<a href="http://future.arts.monash.edu/learning-abroad">http://future.arts.monash.edu/learning-abroad</a>)</span> at Prato that requires an application to be enrolled and may incur additional cost.</li>
<li>The unit may be offered in <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">non-standard teaching periods</a><span class="hbk-print-url">non-standard teaching periods (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census</a>)</span>.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Europe is the birthplace of cinema, and from the silent era through to Italian neo-realism, to the new waves of the 1960s and 70s, European cinema changed the way we see and know the world. In this unit we trace the development of European cinema after the fall of the Berlin Wall and into the 21st century, asking three key questions: How have the changing boundaries and social crises in Europe in the post-Berlin Wall era impacted on cinema? What distinguishes European cinema from others in the global era? Can the cinema still be an appropriate media for reflecting cultures, identity and social change? We will study some of Europe's most influential contemporary films and documentaries. We will examine the tension between the rise of transnational European 'blockbuster' cinema, designed to compete with Hollywood, and traditional European art house filmmaking. We will consider the long-standing relationship between European cinema and the European tradition of film festivals. We will address issues of language, translation and subtitling. And we will also look at political and social implications of important emergent cinemas from this period, including a proliferation of immigrant films that are challenging traditional conceptions of European space and identity. Students will be introduced to films from a range of countries, including France, Belgium, Italy, Germany, Hungary and Spain.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit students will have</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>an understanding of the role cinema plays in contemporary European societies;</li>
<li>an ability to apply relevant cinema and cultural studies concepts;</li>
<li>familiarity with some of Europe's most influential films and documentaries;</li>
<li>skills in the formulation, structuring and written presentation of scholarly analysis of European film and documentaries;</li>
<li>skills in cross-cultural competency and team work through contribution to collaborative projects and on-line sites of learning.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu.au/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2001.html">Bachelor of Global Studies</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Bachelor of Global Studies (<a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2001.html">http://www.monash.edu.au/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2001.html</a>)</span></p>
<p><a href="../aos/communications-and-media-studies">Communications and media studies</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/film-and-screen-studies">Film and screen studies</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/french-studies">French studies</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/german-studies">German studies</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/international-relations">International relations</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/journalism">Journalism</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/spanish-and-latin-american-studies">Spanish and Latin American studies</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">BIO1062</span> - Biology 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BIO1062">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-biological-sciences.html">School of Biological Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Richard Reina">Associate Professor Richard Reina</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Song Keang Peng">Associate Professor Song Keang Peng</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BIO1062&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BIO1062">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BIO1011.html">BIO1011</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>BIO1711, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BMS1021.html">BMS1021</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BIO1022.html">BIO1022</a></span></p>
<p>Students in S2007 Bachelor of Science and Bachelor of Biomedical Science are prohibited from enrolling in this unit.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>A study of the biology of whole organisms, organ systems and cells, including molecular genetics, and the effect of environmental parameters on biological functions. The biology of microbes and animals is emphasised. Ecological factors that are biologically important at the level of integrated whole organisms and at the cellular, subcellular, and biochemical levels are considered for each organism under study. As for <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BIO1011.html">BIO1011</a></span>, the unit is structured to encourage self-paced learning with considerable feedback on individual performance.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Demonstrate a coherent understanding of biology by articulating the methods of biology and explaining why current biological knowledge is both contestable and testable through further inquiry;</li>
<li>Demonstrate an understanding of concepts and processes related to
molecular genetics, genetic engineering, and the physiology of organ systems, including homeostasis, nervous and muscular-skeletal systems, animal reproduction and development and nutrition;</li>
<li>Demonstrate an understanding of microbial diversity, in particular how it relates to human health and disease;</li>
<li>Gather, synthesise and critically evaluate information relevant to biology by applying practical techniques (including Gram staining, gel electrophoresis, and spectrophotometry) and tools to conduct an investigation within the laboratory;</li>
<li>Demonstrate competency in designing experiments, gathering data and analysing and presenting summative data in meaningful and accurate ways;</li>
<li>Communicate scientific principles and information underlying biology-related topics in written or oral formats and using appropriate conventions for scientific attribution;</li>
<li>Work and learn independently and collaboratively while exercising personal, professional and social responsibility that recognises the importance of practising science sustainably, ethically and safely.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 50%</p>
<p>Practical's, online activities, and assessments: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Two 1-hour lectures, one hour of set reading and quizzes, and one 3-hour practical or equivalent online activities</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">ASP5000</span> - Advanced astrophysics research project<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">24 points, SCA Band 2, 0.500 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ASP5000">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-physics-and-astronomy.html">School of Physics and Astronomy</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Michael J Morgan">Professor Michael J Morgan</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Michael J Morgan">Professor Michael J Morgan</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ASP5000">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Enrolment in the Master of Science</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>This unit will be offered annually from Semester 2, 2020</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Students undertake an advanced research project involving original work on a topic chosen in consultation with an academic supervisor. The topic may be a continuation of research completed in <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ASP4000.html">ASP4000</a></span>, enabling a deeper insight into a larger research problem.  In this case, it is expected that the research outcomes will also be suitable for submission for publication in a peer-reviewed international journal.</p>
<p>Alternatively, the project may be a separate topic to <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ASP4000.html">ASP4000</a></span>, but the student must display a more mature research methodology than was required for <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ASP4000.html">ASP4000</a></span>.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Understand, use and explain the basic concepts and principles of the research literature which underpin the chosen area of astrophysics research.</li>
<li>Synthesise and interpret the knowledge gained in the study of the underpinning research literature. This leads to the ability to identify a niche topic or topics within this existing body of literature, which represents a gap in current knowledge. This problem should be suitable for original research.</li>
<li>Solve an outstanding problem or problems in the chosen area for original research.</li>
<li>Present the results of the original research in written form as a thesis, and also present key thesis results in oral form as a final seminar.</li>
<li>Defend the results of the original research in an oral exam.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Seminar 20%</p>
<p>Thesis 80%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>48 hours per week which includes 36 hours of independent research; 7 hours of final seminar and thesis preparation; 3 hours attendance at group meetings, seminars colloquia; 1-hour specialist training and 1-hour consultation with a supervisor.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p>Master of Science in Astrophysics</p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">APG5042</span> - Practices of teaching Englishes for intercultural communication<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-APG5042">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-english-as-an-international-language.html">English as an International Language</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Marc Xu">Dr Marc Xu</a>
        
        (Semester 1)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Atefeh Hadi">Dr Atefeh Hadi</a>
        
        (Semester 2)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Atefeh Hadi">Dr Atefeh Hadi</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=APG5042&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-APG5042">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (Online)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>APG4020</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit introduces students to the practical aspects of teaching World Englishes in a variety of multilingual, intra/international contexts. It covers diverse topics that equip students with knowledge and skills to teach World Englishes. Topics range from instructional language in a World-Englishes lesson to curriculum development for World-Englishes courses, and from intercultural pedagogy to assessing multidialectal and intercultural competencies. Students are provided with the opportunity to observe the practices of teaching World Englishes, to develop their own World-Englishes curriculum, to practise teaching World Englishes, and to engage in critical reflections and evaluations of their own practices.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>demonstrate advanced understanding of the practical aspects of teaching World Englishes in a variety of international contexts;</li>
<li>exhibit the skills to teach World Englishes in a variety of international contexts;</li>
<li>develop a learning curriculum and syllabus for teaching Englishes for multidialectal/international communication;</li>
<li>critically engage in evaluating practices of teaching World Englishes;</li>
<li>Profile pedagogical ideas that are informed by the latest literature on teaching Englishes for multidialectal/international communication.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 288 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/applied-linguistics">Applied linguistics</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">ADD5092</span> - Research methods 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">0 points, SCA Band 1, 0.000 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ADD5092">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Fiona Macdonald">Dr Fiona Macdonald</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Fiona Macdonald">Dr Fiona Macdonald</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ADD5092&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ADD5092&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ADD5092">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus</a>)</li><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus</a>)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (External Candidature)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ADD5091.html">ADD5091</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Students must be enrolled in the MADA Doctor of Philosophy (course code 1322)</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Research Methods 2 examines theory models and investigative methods in contemporary research. The candidate develops a conceptual framework of studio research and exegesis or thesis that identifies the relations between research intention and research method.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit candidates will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Have further developed the discursive approach to the subject of their research and its field of inquiry;</li>
<li>Have further developed the critical understanding of methodologies in contemporary research;</li>
<li>Be able to argue the logic of their research process;</li>
<li>Be able to situate the relevance of their research within a contemporary context;</li>
<li>Have further developed the forms, languages and conventions applicable to their research;</li>
<li>Have developed the conceptual framework, research design and logic of their research process to sustain an exegetical or thesis elaboration of their research.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>10 hours per week including 2 contact hours plus 8 hours of independent study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">OPM5003</span> - Managing project knowledge<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-OPM5003">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chivonne Algeo">Associate Professor Chivonne Algeo</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=OPM5003&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-OPM5003">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>At least 12 points of level 4 OPM units.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT5057.html">FIT5057</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT5178.html">FIT5178</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT5194.html">FIT5194</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit explores the role of formal and informal knowledge networks in project delivery. It focuses on developing an understanding of how project managers acquire and exchange knowledge, and how this knowledge impacts on their actions. The unit incorporates concepts and theories from various disciplines aligned to project management and knowledge management to enrich students' understanding of the socio-technical aspects of project management.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Evaluate, assess and communicate different project management perspectives to meet contextual demands.</li>
<li>Critically reflect on and improve practice through effective management of knowledge in a project context.</li>
<li>Contrast and assess the most effective communication techniques to form knowledge networks to manage different project scenarios.</li>
<li>Critically analyse and identify tools and techniques to acquire and exchange knowledge using technical and social approaches in a project context.</li>
<li>Design and apply creative communication techniques to present group responses across different stakeholders and scenarios.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>In-semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Workshop; which comprise lectures and tutorials in block-mode workshops held twice during the semester for two and a half consecutive days, with up to 140 hours of combined face-to-face time attending workshops and off-campus preparation and assessment work.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p>Project management</p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>
